Winston Christie-Blick
Product | Human-Centered Design | Education
August 23, 2012, Daniel was senior to Winston but didn’t manage directly

Dear Fellow Educator,Winston was a founding teacher at Teleos Prep Academy, one of the family of Great Hearts academies.  Winston has strengths of a successful Great Hearts educator, as well as the sorts of leadership inherent in teaching at an achievement gap school like Teleos. Here are some highlights from his career so far:•	developing the sixth grade Literature/Composition and U.S. History curricula (including the creation of hundreds of carefully crafted lesson plans, aligned assignments and assessments, and engaging projects and PowerPoints)•	bringing self-researched teaching techniques from top performing charter networks into his math classes and sharing these strategies with other faculty members•	organizing the first extracurricular honors literary society to challenge high achieving sixth and seventh graders•	mentoring incoming teachers (including tens of hours spent informally working with his replacement—Christina Lucas— this summer, and reformatting and transferring hundreds of curriculum documents so she would more readily pick up where he left off)•	transmitting to his students a sense of urgency surrounding their schoolwork, a passion for exploration and a willingness to take risks while approaching unfamiliar material or problem-solving, and a genuine interest in grappling with compelling ideas, whether they be found in Literature, current events, a History reading, or a Math textbook.This past year he met his yearlong performance goals in all subject areas, with 84 percent of students passing AIMS Writing standards, 95 percent of students passing Reading, and 89 percent of students passing Math. Over half of the class (55 percent) scored “exceeds” on the Math portion of AIMS. Winston has a bright future as a master teacher and educational leader.Sincerely,Dr. Daniel Scoggin,CEO, Great Hearts Academies

summary: Dan attended Santa Clara University in California as an English Literature major. He spent his junior year abroad at the University of Durham in England. While completing his Ph.D. in English Literature at the Claremont Graduate University, Dan taught at Harvey Mudd College, The Phoenix Institute at the University of Notre Dame, Mesa Community College, and coached basketball at Pomona College. In 1998, he returned to his hometown to teach humanities and coach at Tempe Preparatory Academy. In 1999, he was promoted from teacher to headmaster of Tempe Prep and oversaw the first six graduating classes of the Academy. In 2004, Dan authored the Great Hearts business plan, secured its initial grant funding, and was promoted to CEO of this charter management organization. In this role, he has grown the corporation’s central office and has overseen the founding of over 20 academies.  All graduates attend college; more importantly, their hearts and minds are shaped for noble leadership and a destiny beyond themselves. Dan is a 2008-2009 Piper Fellow and attended the Stanford University Executive Education Program. He is also a Pahara-Aspen Education Fellow (class of 2013). He is now working with the national board and executive staff on the founding of schools in Texas, with the first academy opened in San Antonio and more to be founded there and in Dallas/Ft. Worth. Other regions across the country are also being considered for future expansion. The purpose of Great Hearts is to restore American public schooling through a return to Classical, liberal arts education dedicated to the pursuit of Truth, Beauty, and Goodness.
name: Daniel Scoggin
title: Co-Founder, Great Hearts Academies
